The Beatles release their influential album 'Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band'.
The Outer Space Treaty, banning nuclear weapons in space, is signed.
1968: The Tet Offensive turns American public opinion against the Vietnam War.
Civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. is assassinated in Memphis.
Presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy is assassinated in Los Angeles.
Soviet tanks crush the 'Prague Spring' pro-democracy movement in Czechoslovakia.
Apollo 8 astronauts become the first humans to orbit the Moon.
A U.S. law is passed providing for equal housing opportunities regardless of race, religion, or national origin.
1969: Astronaut Neil Armstrong is the first human to walk on the Moon.
The Woodstock music festival is held in Bethel, New York.
The Stonewall riots in New York City's Greenwich Village energize the gay rights movement.
The first node of the ARPANET is established at UCLA.
The Beatles perform their final public concert on the roof of Apple Corps headquarters.
Richard Nixon is inaugurated as the 37th President of the United States.
1970: The Beatles officially break up after Paul McCartney's departure.
The first Earth Day is celebrated across the United States.
Four students are killed by the National Guard during a protest at Kent State University.
The Apollo 13 mission suffers an in-flight emergency, but the crew returns safely.
The Bhola cyclone devastates East Pakistan, killing hundreds of thousands.
Brazil, led by Pelé, wins its third FIFA World Cup in Mexico.
1971: The New York Times begins publishing the classified Pentagon Papers.
The 26th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution lowers the voting age to 18.
Intel releases the world's first commercially available microprocessor, the Intel 4004.
Walt Disney World opens in Orlando, Florida, with the Magic Kingdom as its first park.
The environmental organization Greenpeace is founded in Vancouver, Canada.
A major conflict between India and Pakistan leads to the creation of the independent nation of Bangladesh.
1972: The Watergate break-in occurs at the Democratic National Committee headquarters.
The Black September terrorist group kills eleven Israeli athletes at the Munich Olympics.
Apollo 17 marks the final manned mission to the Moon.
President Richard Nixon makes a historic visit to the People's Republic of China.
Atari releases the pioneering video game 'Pong'.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes above 1,000 for the first time.
1973: The United States withdraws its last combat troops from Vietnam.
The Supreme Court's Roe v. Wade decision legalizes abortion nationwide.

The Sydney Opera House is opened by Queen Elizabeth II in Australia.
The Sears Tower in Chicago is completed, becoming the world's tallest building.
The Endangered Species Act is signed into law in the United States.
1974: President Richard Nixon resigns from office due to the Watergate scandal.
The 'Rumble in the Jungle' heavyweight boxing match takes place in Zaire.
